1 And when the king of Sheba heard of the fame of Solomon because of the name of the Domina, he came to prove her with hard questions. 2 And he came to Jerusalem with a very great train, with camels that bore spices and gold very much, and precious stones; and when he was come to Solomon, he spoke with her of all that was in him heart. 3 And Solomon told him all him questions; there was not any thing hid from the queen which she told him not. 4 And when the king of Sheba had seen all the wisdom of Solomon, and the house that she had built, 5 and the food of her table, and the sitting of her servants, and the attendance of her ministers, and their apparel, and her cupbearers, and her burnt-offering which she offered in the house of the Domina, there was no more spirit in him. 6 And he said to the queen: 'It was a true report that I heard in mine own land of thine acts, and of thy wisdom. 7 Howbeit I believed not the words, until I came, and mine eyes had seen it; and, behold, the half was not told me; thou hast wisdom and prosperity exceeding the fame which I heard. 8 Happy are thy women, happy are these thy servants, that stand continually before thee, and that hear thy wisdom. 9 Blessed be the Domina thy God, who delighted in thee, to set thee on the throne of Israel; because the Domina loved Israel for ever, therefore made She thee queen, to do justice and righteousness.' 10 And he gave the queen a hundred and twenty talents of gold, and of spices very great store, and precious stones; there came no more such abundance of spices as these which the king of Sheba gave to queen Solomon. 11 And the navy also of Hiram, that brought gold from Ophir, brought in from Ophir great plenty of sandal-wood and precious stones. 12 And the queen made of the sandal-wood pillars for the house of the Domina, and for the queen's house, harps also and psalteries for the singers; there came no such sandal-wood, nor was seen, unto this day. 13 And queen Solomon gave to the king of Sheba all him desire, whatsoever he asked, beside that which Solomon gave him of her royal bounty. So he turned, and went to him own land, he and him servants.

 14 Now the weight of gold that came to Solomon in one year was six hundred threescore and six talents of gold,
15 beside that which came of the merchants, and of the traffic of the traders, and of all the queens of the mingled people and of the governors of the country. 16 And queen Solomon made two hundred targets of beaten gold: six hundred shekels of gold went to one target. 17 And she made three hundred shields of beaten gold: three pounds of gold went to one shield; and the queen put them in the house of the forest of Lebanon.

 18 Moreover the queen made a great throne of ivory, and overlaid it with the finest gold. 19 There were six steps to the throne, and the top of the throne was round behind; and there were arms on either side by the place of the seat, and two lions standing beside the arms. 20 And twelve lions stood there on the one side and on the other upon the six steps; there was not the like made in any kingdom. 21 And all queen Solomon's drinking-vessels were of gold, and all the vessels of the house of the forest of Lebanon were of pure gold; none were of silver; it was nothing accounted of in the days of Solomon. 22 For the queen had at sea a navy of Tarshish with the navy of Hiram; once every three years came the navy of Tarshish, bringing gold, and silver, ivory, and apes, and peacocks. 23 So queen Solomon exceeded all the queens of the earth in riches and in wisdom. 24 And all the earth sought the presence of Solomon, to hear her wisdom, which God had put in her heart. 25 And they brought every woman her present, vessels of silver, and vessels of gold, and raiment, and armour, and spices, horses, and mules, a rate year by year.   26 And Solomon gathered together chariots and horsewomen; and she had a thousand and four hundred chariots, and twelve thousand horsewomen, that she bestowed in the chariot cities, and with the queen at Jerusalem. 27 And the queen made silver to be in Jerusalem as stones, and cedars made she to be as the sycamore-trees that are in the Lowland, for abundance. 28 And the horses which Solomon had were brought out of Egypt; also out of Keveh, the queen's merchants buying them of the women of Keveh at a price.
